And due to the electron-donating effect of P ligands and the strong multicoordination bonds between Rh and P, the Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst exhibited a little higher TOF of 1550h−1 than that of optimized Monsanto process and maintained relatively stable activity for near 180h under 2.5MPa, 195°C. In Contrast to the Monsanto homogeneous system, the Rh heterogeneous methanol carbonylation universally displays lower activity and stability. Here, a single site catalyst Rh-POL-PPh3 was successfully prepared by impregnation of the Rh2(CO)4Cl2 dichloromethane solution, and applied to heterogeneous methanol carbonylation in a continuous fixed-bed reactor for the first time. Due to single site Rh species and the electron-donating effect of P ligands and the strong multicoordination bonds between Rh and P, the Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst exhibited a little higher TOF of 1550h−1 than that of optimized Monsanto process and maintained relatively stable activity for near 180h under 2.5MPa, 195°C. Thus, POL-PPh3 not only acts as a stable support but also a promotion of methanol carbonylation process. Keywords Heterogeneous methanol carbonylation Porous organic ligands Rh-P coordination bonds Single site catalyst 1 Introduction Methanol carbonylation [1] is one of the most important industrialized homogeneous processes [2]. Monsanto company first established and industrialized a methyl-iodide promoted Rh-based homogeneous catalyst which presented great performance in activity and selectivity in mild reaction conditions (180–220°C, 2–4MPa) [3,4]. However, the requirement of dissolved Rh species, leads to a costly purification recycle process [1,5]. Since oxidative addition of methyl iodide to the initial active species [Rh(CO)2I2]− (initial nucleophilic attack by Rh on the carbon of methyl iodide) is the rate-determining step in the mechanism of Monsanto catalytic cycle (shown in Scheme 1 ), introduction of strong electron-donating ligands, such as phosphine ligands, may increase the activity of Rh catalyst [6]. As an alternative to the Monsanto process with product separation and intermittent production problem, heterogenization of homogeneous catalyst in methanol carbonylation process [1,7–10] has been reported. Due to that Rh heterogeneous systems are generally less active and stable than the Monsanto process, some phosphine pendant groups acting as an promotion [6] were introduced into the polymer support so as to form Rh-P coordination bonds [8]. However, the Rh centers cannot be strongly captured by the P ligands due to the limitation of P concentration in the modified polymer supports. Thus, the designation of stable heterogeneous catalyst with high concentration exposed phosphine is a key issue. Nowadays, among various POPs (porous organic polymers)[11–24], a series of self-polymerized POPs called POLs (porous organic ligands) [14,15,25] not only contain much high content of exposed N or P group in framework in order to immobilize metal atom or ion in single sites [26,27], but also promote stability of heterogeneous coordinated catalysts. Thus, the incorporation of organometallic complexes into POLs may offers an opportunity to combine the advantages of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts in methanol carbonylation. In our previous work, POL-PPh3 was successfully synthesized [27] and have been applied in hydroformylation [27] and hydrogenation [28]. However, due to the harsh reaction temperature and the corrosivity from methyl iodide, the stability and high activity of catalysts based on POL-PPh3 for carbonylation is still challenging. Herein, in our present work, POL-PPh3 coordinated Rh catalyst (Rh-POL-PPh3) was successfully prepared and applied to heterogeneous methanol carbonylation in a continuous fixed-bed reactor. The Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst exhibited somewhat higher activity than that of Monsanto process and maintained stable activity for near 180h. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All reagents were of analytical grade and used as purchased without further purification unless otherwise stated. CH2Cl2 was dried with molecular sieves and distilled before use. And Rh2(CO)4Cl2 was purchased from J&K Chemical Ltd.All operations were carried out under argon. POL-PPh3 was synthesized according to our previous work [27]. The Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst was prepared by impregnation. As a typical run, 5.7mg of Rh2(CO)4Cl2 was stirred and dissolved in 20ml of CH2Cl2 under argon atmosphere, followed by the addition of 1.0g of POL-PPh3. After stirring for 24h under argon atmosphere at 25°C, the Rh-POL-PPh3 was obtained after filtering, washing with 60ml CH2Cl2 and drying at 60°C under vacuum to remove CH2Cl2. And as an example for contrast, the Rh/AC was also prepared by impregnation. As a typical run, 5.7mg of Rh2(CO)4Cl2 was stirred and dissolved in 20ml of deionized water, and 1g of activated carbon (made from coconut husk, 20–40mesh, surface area=1300m2/g) was added to the precursor solution and dried at 65°C for 6h. The catalyst was fully dried under 120°C for 12h. Final catalyst was calcined at 300°C for 4h under argon atmosphere. 2.2 Characterization The Rh-POL-PPh3 (Rh content=0.26wt% or 0. 025mmol/gcat) was characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS-mapping), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), inductively coupled plasma (ICP), and solid state 31P MAS NMR and X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS). SEM and EDS mapping were performed on a JSM-7800F scanning electron microscope. TEM study was performed on a JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope. HAADF-STEM was performed on a JEM-ARM200F. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) was measured on a PerkinElmer apparatus optima 7300DV. The complete digestion of the powder samples on an Anton Paar Multiwave 300 system would be necessary before ICP testing. As a typical run, 0.05g of sample was digested absolutely under microwave digestion for 30min at 800W in the existence of 5ml of aquaregia and 2ml of H2O2, followed by addition of water to 50ml. Based on 85% H3PO4 as reference, the solid state 31P MAS NMR was characterized on VARIAN Infinity plus spectrometer equipped with a 2.5mm probe at a frequency of 161.8MHz. Insitu-XPS analysis were carried out on an Thermofisher ESCALAB 250Xi with Al Kα radiation. Rh-POL-PPh3 was pretreated by the mixed gas 5%CO/He under atmospheric pressure and 195°C for 90min in XPS apparatus, followed by XPS test under vacuum without exposure to air. The binding energies were calibrated with the C 1s level of adventitious carbon (284.6eV) as an internal standard reference. 2.3 Vapor methanol carbonylation of Rh-POL-PPh3 The methanol carbonylation of Rh-POL-PPh3 or Rh/AC was conducted in a continuous flow fixed-bed Zirconium reactor with an inner diameter of 6mm. The catalyst dosage was 0.1500g (containing 0.0044mmol Rh) each test. The reactor was heated at a rate of 5°C/min from 30°C to 195°C under 2.5MPa with a CO flow of 1.34mmol/min. Then a premixed liquid solution of methanol and methyl iodide (nMeOH/nMeI =6.21:1) was introduced into the Hastelloy vaporizer portion upstream from the reactor by HPLC pump at the rate of 0.05ml/min. Thus, the overall molar ratio of MeOH/MeI/CO=1/0.16/1.4. The liquid product was collected by the condenser under 3°C. The tail gas was analyzed on-line using an Agilent 7890A gas chromatography with a Porapak-QS column and TCD. The liquid product was analyzed off-line with an Agilent 7890A gas chromatography using an FID with an FFAP column and isobutyl alcohol as an internal standard. The rhodium complex is immobilized by the formation of Rh-P coordination bonds between Rh precursor and POL-PPh3. The 0.26wt% (or 0.022mmol/gcat) loading of rhodium in fresh Rh-POL-PPh3 was measured by ICP-OES shown in Table 1 . Table 2 showed the activities of Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst and Rh homogeneous system under the same pressure and temperature. The TOF for acetyl production of typical Monsanto system is about 1470h−1, which was consistent with our own homogeneous experimental result. In Rh homogeneous system, high water concentration can stabilize the catalyst in active form without precipitation [1]. And the unavoidable additive “CH3COOH” leads to the esterification with methanol into methyl acetate, which (rather than methanol) is activated by HI [1]. However, Rh-POL-PPh3 in methanol carbonylation was about 1550h−1 under 195°C and 2.5MPa, which a little exceeded that of Rh homogeneous system. Despite of the general knowledge that heterogeneous catalysts have been always proven to be less active than corresponding homogeneous systems, the activity of Rh-POL-PPh3 always slightly outstrips that of the optimized Rh homogeneous system even without addition of a large amount of acetic acid as promotions and stabilizers. It can be supposed that owing to Rh-P coordination bonds, which were confirmed later, P species as a strongly donating ligand transfers electrons to Rh ion center and enhances the rate-determining step of oxidative addition of methyl iodide to Rh(I) center. And the Rh-POL-PPh3 catalysts with different Rh loading amount have been evaluated in Table 3 . It's reasonable that the TOFs of Rh-POL-PPh3 catalysts loading Rh 2wt% (0.019mmol/gcat) and 0.026wt% (0.0025mmol/gcat) were similar, which implied that Rh species in POL-PPh3 probably catalyzed methanol carbonlytion in single site. Additionally, the methanol carbonylation performances of Rh-POL-PPh3 under different temperatures and pressures were also tested. Temperature was a key role in this catalytic methanol carbonylation system. In Table 4 , under 180°C and 2.5MPa, the TOF of acetyl species was 388h−1. If temperature increased to 210°C, the TOF rose to 1921h−1. When continuous increasing temperature to 225°C, it was not obviously helpful for improving methanol carbonylation activity. And Table 5 demonstrated the effect of pressure of the reaction on the methanol carbonylation performance. The TOF was no more than 233h−1 below 1.5MPa pressure. When the pressure rose to 2.5MPa and 5MPa, the TOF increased sharply to 1394h−1 and 1913h−1 respectively, which implies that higher CO pressure might favor coordination of CO with Rh to form more actived [CO]* species, leading to the higher TOF. Hence, according to the evaluation of Rh-POL-PPh3 above, the operation condition of 2.5MPa, 195°C was chosen to test the catalyst stability. As clearly shown in Fig. 1 , the TOF of CH3COOCH3 and CH3COOH over Rh-POL-PPh3 maintained about 1500h−1 for near 180h. And the performance of Rh/AC (Rh2(CO)4Cl2 loaded on activated carbon, 0.3wt% Rh loading) in methanol carbonylation was also tested. The TOF of Rh/AC decreased continuously from 1500h−1 to 590h−1 for only time on stream 65h. The obvious stability differences between the two catalysts were supposed to be originated from the differences of the chemical bonds between Rh species and the supports. As for Rh/AC, the active Rh+ species may easily undergo valence alternation to zero valence or leach from the support due to the weak interaction between Rh species and support under high pressure CO during carbonylation process. However, as for Rh-POL-PPh3, the considerably high exposed P content and high mole ratio of P/Rh in Rh-POL-PPh3 result in the formation of multicoordination bonds between Rh and P. It is meaning that a single Rh atom is seized by many coordinated exposed P atoms. Furthermore, there are excessive phosphine ligands in POL-PPh3 around the Rh species. Even if partial Rh-P bond cleavage occurs, the available excess exposed P for coordination can grasp Rh species to avoid Rh leaching and maintain active sites. It is worth mentioning that the stability of our polymer catalyst under serious corrosivity originated from methyl iodide and relatively high temperature (195°C) versified the strong coordination of P to capture Rh species. 3.2 Analysis of characterization The dispersion state of Rh in fresh and spent Rh-POL-PPh3 catalysts were characterized by TEM, SEM-EDS mapping, HADDF-STEM, and rhodium valence of Rh-POL-PPh3 catalysts were characterized by XPS. In addition, the coordination of Rh-P of Rh-POL-PPh3 catalysts was obtained from the solid state 31P MAS NMR and XPS. The SEM-EDS mapping of high magnification micrographs shown in Fig. S1 and S2 reveal that Rh species in both fresh and spent Rh-POL-PPh3 catalysts disperse very uniformly under 3–4μm scale and there is no discerned difference for the Rh element density on EDS maps of fresh Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst as well as spent one. None metal particles can be found by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis (Fig. S3), which means that the Rh species in fresh and spent Rh-POL-PPh3 catalysts are highly dispersed over polymer support. Furthermore, as can be seen from Fig. 2 (A and B), the Rh species in fresh Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst are well dispersed as isolated single sites (labelled as red circles) in the catalyst under high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HADDF-STEM). Aberration-corrected HADDF images of the spent Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst after near 180h continuous methanol carbonylation (Fig. 2(C and D)) reveal clearly that the Rh species still retains their isolated monodisperse state (labelled as red circles) without any observable occurrence of sintering or aggregation. And XPS was applied to judge rhodium valence in Rh-POL-PPh3 and existent of Rh-P bonds. It has been confirmed that the XPS of Rh0 and Rh+1 shows the binding energies of Rh3d5/2 are 310.0eV and 307.4eV respectively [30,31]. As shown in Fig. 3 and Table S1, the binding energies of the rhodium in fresh Rh-POL-PPh3 or in situ Rh-POL-PPh3 which has been pretreated by 5%CO/He mixed gas at 195°C for 90min in XPS apparatus are both at about 308.4eV, which can be inferred that the rhodium valence of them are both between +1 and 0 (labelled as Rhδ+) [32]. Thus the results prove the electron transfer from P to rhodium and the existent of the Rh-P coordination bonds in Rh-POL-PPh3. To further confirm the formation of Rh-P coordination bonds, the solid state 31P MAS NMR characterization of fresh and spent Rh-POL-PPh3 catalysts was also employed. As shown in Fig. S4, the resonance at −5.8ppm [27,33] is ascribed to the vacant P species in Rh-POL-PPh3. And despite of that some researchers hold the view that the resonance at 26.4ppm is judged as oxidized phosphine, others in general believe that the resonance at 26.4ppm [27,34] is ascribed to the coordinated P species. Therefore, according to the XPS results of Rh-POL-PPh3, it is reasonable to believe that the resonance at 26.4ppm indicates the Rh-P coordination bond is formed in both fresh and spent Rh-POL-PPh3 catalysts. And the 0.23wt% (or 0.022mmol/gcat) Rh loading in the spent Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst by ICP-OES implied that there was little Rh leaching of Rh-POL-PPh3 after near 180h methanol carbonylation process (Table 1). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a single site Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst was prepared and applied to methanol carbonylation process. Due to the formation of Rh-P coordination bonds in Rh-POL-PPh3, the catalyst imitated the homogeneous process in single site and showed high activity as well as relatively excellent stability for methanol carbonylation. POL-PPh3 possesses dual function in the process, on the one hand, POL-PPh3 acts as a support containing high content exposed P for coordination to impede rhodium leaching under the reaction conditions of high temperature and pressure; on the other hand, it donates electrons to rhodium center to increase the nucleophilicity of rhodium and to accelerate oxidative addition of methyl iodide to active Rh center, which is thought as the rate-determining step during the title reaction. Even without adding acetic acid, the so-prepared Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst displayed slightly higher activity than the optimized Monsanto process. During near 180h of reaction running in a fixed-bed reactor, the Rh-POL-PPh3 catalyst showed much better stability than Rh/AC.
